learning_outcomes.description: Draw on a range of interdisciplinary skills to identify, critique and understand socio-cultural issues.
Demonstrate integration of prior and current scholarship into a cohesive interdisciplinary context.
Appreciate the breadth and cross-cultural nature of the problems to which humanities research offers potential advanced and alternative thinking.
Discuss socio-cultural problems with different audiences at appropriate levels.
Conceptualise the skills pertinent to humanities interdisciplinary research.
Critically reflect on your own position in society, and the future work market.

assessments.task_description: Participation is essential for passing this course, and requires you to interact respectfully and learn from your peers. Students are expected to participate in seminar discussions and relevant seminar tasks. This assessment requires you to show evidence of preparation for seminars and participate in large and small group discussions with relevant and well-focused comments. Interaction in lectures and on Padlet is not essential, but will earn you additional points.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description: In this short reflective text (500-750 words), each student will position themselves (their social, cultural and academic background) in relation to one of the texts and/or origin stories discussed in weeks 2-4, and construct an argument about its place in modern culture and/or humanities discourse. This is an IN-CLASS closed-book assessment, that should be submitted under examination conditions in your tutorials in week 5.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Video for Advanced Humanities Youtube Channel
assessments.task_description:
Each student will submit a short video or podcast presentation (7-10 minutes, which is about 1,000 words) on a focused topic within the general research topic area 'Boundaries of Humanity/Humanities'



A SELECTION OF EXCEPTIONALLY GOOD VIDEOS/PODCASTS WILL BE POSTED ON THE ADVANCED HUMANITIES YOUTUBE CHANNEL
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
In this critical reflection, you will be required to use an Artificial Intelligence (AI) model, ChatGPT, to generate an employment application package (including a CV and cover letter) for a graduate position within a chosen industry (see options in section A below). You will then critically reflect on the presence/absence of cross-cultural nuance and diversity within the AI-generated material, considering it from the perspective of your chosen industry, one or two specific perspectives (see options in section B below) and reading material studied in the course. In doing so, you are required to reflect on your own cultural background and influences, demonstrate an understanding of cultural complexity, and identify cultural influences that inform your response.

This critical reflection (ca 1,500 words) should also refer to appropriate secondary reading material. These resources could include required or recommended readings selected from the HUMN2200 course profile, alongside cultural studies research material and non-academic commentary on themes such as disciplinarity, diversity, and the cultural impact of AI in industry. 

Your application package should focus on ONE industry from Section A, and your critical reflection should consider it from ONE or TWO perspectives in Section B:


 

SECTION A):

1.     Social Work and/or Youth Counselling

2.     Judiciary and Corrections

3.     Education – Primary & Secondary

4.     Education – Tertiary & Research 

5.     Government or Public Service

6.     Libraries, Galleries or Arts Institutions

 

SECTION B):

1.     Gender Identity

2.     Age

3.     Education

4.     Cultural Identity

5.     Religion

6.     Embodiment


Your submission should include BOTH your AI-generated employment application package and your critical reflection. Your application package is not included in the word count.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

Guest Interview: Professor Tracey Bunda


Required Reading: Selection from Louise Gwenneth Phillips, Tracey Bunda, Elizabeth P. Quintero, 'Research Through, With and As Storying' (2018)
